Hearing.Statement: <opening>OPENING STATEMENT OF HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN, A REPRESENTATIVE INCONGRESS FROM THE STATE OF TENNESSEE</opening> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">Mrs. Blackburn. Good morning, everyone.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">We are delighted that you all are here and that you're joining us as the Communications and Technology Subcommittee is kicking off the 115th Congress.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">I guess kick off is the right word to use because we are looking at the Super Bowl this weekend. So everybody pick your team.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">Our subcommittee features a few new faces and also some familiar faces in new roles, and before we begin I'd like to take a moment for a brief introduction.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">Mr. Lance is our vice chairman and he is going to be a valuable partner in all of our endeavors. His understanding on the issues and his experience as a senior member of this committee will be a great asset to us on the subcommittee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">I am also excited to introduce the new Republican members of the subcommittee: Mr. Flores, Ms. Brooks, Ms. Walters, Mr. Costello. We welcome their eagerness and their talents to these issues.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">I want to congratulate Mr. Doyle, the new ranking member. He has been consistently active on these issues through the years. I am looking forward to working with him.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">As I have so focused on these coms and technology issues I've appreciated the fact that Mr. Doyle kind of like me chose to opt himself in to the discussion on these issues and he is joined by three new members on his side.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">I know that he is going to be ready to introduce them in a few moments. Let me begin with my opening statement. Get myself organized here.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">As we continue the subcommittee's work, modernizing the laws around communications and technology and striving to promote innovation and investment it only makes sense to begin by taking a look at one of the agencies tasked with developing telecommunications policy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">The last NTIA reauthorization was adopted in, get this, 1992. It is far past time that we again reauthorize the agency and the first step in the process is to examine the role of the agency past, present and future in crafting policies that will achieve our shared goals.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">We are pleased to have three witnesses today that can speak to their experiences as head of the NTIA. We are so grateful for your time and for your insights and I am certain they are going to give us the needed perspective on the work that the agency has done and also, hopefully, give us some good ideas on how to empower the NTIA going forward.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">One of the biggest bipartisan priorities for the subcommittee over the years has been satisfying the demand for additional spectrum for commercial use.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">As the FCC winds down the broadcast incentive auction, one of the last opportunities for reallocation of commercial spectrum to other commercial users we are again turning our focus to federally-held spectrum. The government holds a large amount of spectrum and we recognize that they require much of it for carrying out critical government missions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">However, we also want to be certain that the government is armed with the best technology and is using that spectrum as efficiently as possible. The dividend from this investment in our government agencies will be more spectrum to meet more broadband demands.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">Broadband deployment is America's greatest infrastructure challenge of this decade and it is up to us to rise to the occasion of meeting this demand.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">We will have long said that spectrum will need to be an all of the above solution and NTIA will be an essential player in any discussion moving forward. In additional to spectrum policy, NTIA plays a leading role in public safety and cybersecurity policy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">They serve as a liaison for interagency cooperation and standard setting in both of these areas promoting safer and more secure communications networks.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">We have seen time and again in recent months how serious cyber threats are we will need to use all of our tools to combat these attacks, especially when it comes to critical infrastructure.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">NTIA has the capability to bring together a diverse group of government stakeholders to address the problem and develop best practices. We must ensure that we empower them to be effective and efficient in combating cyberattacks and promoting strong public safety networks.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">The communication sector is vibrant, thriving, and the government agencies that handle these issues should reflect that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">Today, we are going to look at how to enable the NTIA to craft thoughtful telecom policy that promotes continued innovation and investment.</paragraph>

<opening>Prepared statement of Hon. Marsha Blackburn</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Hon. Marsha Blackburn">I thank our witnesses for their thoughtful testimony and I look forward to a robust discussion on this important agency and at this time I yield 5 minutes to the ranking member.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Hon. Marsha Blackburn">As we continue this subcommittee's work modernizing the laws around communications and technology, and striving to promote innovation and investment, it only makes sense to begin by taking a look at one of the agencies tasked with developing telecommunications policy. The last NTIA reauthorization was adopted in 1992. It is far past time that we again reauthorize the agency, and a first step in the process is to examine the role of the agency, past, present, and future in crafting policies that will achieve our shared goals.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Hon. Marsha Blackburn">We are pleased to have three witnesses today that can speak to their experiences as heads of NTIA. I'm certain they will provide us with valuable perspective on the work that the agency has done, but also hopefully give us good ideas as to how to empower NTIA going forward.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Hon. Marsha Blackburn">One of the biggest bipartisan priorities for this subcommittee over the years has been satisfying the demand for additional spectrum for commercial use. As the FCC winds down the broadcast incentive auction, one of the last opportunities for reallocation of commercial spectrum to other commercial users, we are again turning our focus to federally held spectrum. The government holds a large amount of spectrum, and we recognize that they require much of it for carrying out critical government missions. However, we also want to be certain that the government is armed with the best technology, and is using spectrum as efficiently as possible. The dividend from this investment in our government agencies will be more spectrum to meet broadband needs. Broadband deployment is America's greatest infrastructure challenge and we must rise to the occasion. We have long said that spectrum will need to be an ``all of the above'' solution, and NTIA will be an essential player in any discussion moving forward.</paragraph>

<opening>OPENING STATEMENT OF HON. MICHAEL F. DOYLE, A REPRESENTATIVE INCONGRESS FROM THE COMMONWEALTH OF PENNSYLVANIA</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="HON. MICHAEL F. DOYLE"> In addition to spectrum policy, NTIA plays a leading role in public safety and cyber security policy. NTIA serves as a liaison for interagency cooperation and standard setting in both of these areas, promoting safer and more secure communications networks. We have seen time and again in recent months how serious cyber threats are, and we will need to use all tools at our disposal to combat these attacks-especially when it comes to critical infrastructure. NTIA has the capability to bring together a diverse group of government stakeholders to address the problem and develop best practices. We must ensure that we empower NTIA to be as effective and efficient as possible in combatting cyber attacks and promoting strong public safety networks. The communications sector is vibrant and thriving, and the government agencies that handle these issues should reflect that. Today, we will look at how to enable NTIA to craft thoughtful telecommunications policy that promotes continued innovation and investment. I thank our witnesses for their thoughtful testimony and look forward to a robust discussion on this important agency. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Well, I want to thank you, Madam Chair, for holding this hearing and I want to congratulate you on your new role. I look forward to working with you and having a productive partnership and I am glad you like opt in. I do, too.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Doyle">I also want to thank my colleagues on the committee for giving me this opportunity and introduce our two new members, Raul Ruiz from California and Debbie Dingell from Michigan-- both good members and I think will be good members for this committee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Doyle">I want to thank the outstanding panel that's here today. We look forward to your testimony. As the chair said, we are here today to discuss reauthorizing the National Telecommunications and Information Administration, an agency charged with providing the president and the executive branch with fact- based expert policy recommendations on telecommunications, information, and internet issues.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Doyle">NTIA is also responsible for managing the federal government's use of spectrum and it has been instrumental in clearing government-held spectrum and making it available for commercial use.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Doyle">In the process, tens of billions of dollars have been raised for the federal government. NTIA is also working with federal agencies to find new and creative ways to share underutilized spectrum resources and that's important because maximizing our finite spectrum resources will be critical as we move to the fifth generation wireless networks and beyond.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Doyle">NTIA's Institutes for Telecommunication Sciences located in Colorado are key to this mission. Last year, the funding for this lab was 23 percent below the president's request. Our lack of investment here could have serious implications for this agency's ability to accomplish its mission.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Doyle">We want to ensure that this agency has the authority, the tools, and the personnel it needs to do its job. NTIA also plays a critical role in convening government agencies, industry experts and academics to tackle complex problems through their multi-stakeholder process.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Doyle">This process has been used to address evolving issues such as cybersecurity, the internet of things, UAVs, and many others.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Doyle">This is a well-managed, orderly, and inclusive process that enables the federal government to thoroughly grasp and effectively address complex issues, and more than that, this agency has repeatedly proved its worth beyond just clearing spectrum.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Under the leadership of our panel, NTIA ran the DTV converter coupon program and the BTOP program to deploy broadband infrastructure and stood up FirstNet, the public safety broadband network authority.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Doyle">They have learned valuable lessons along the way. BTOP is now Broadband USA, a program to help communities expand broadband and promote its adoption.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Doyle">My hope is that as we talk about infrastructure investment in this country we look to agencies like NTIA which have extensive experience in this area to help manage and direct these investments for our future.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Doyle">My hope in reauthorizing NTIA is that we empower this agency to continue doing its job and that they continue to have a seat at the table and continue to provide fact-based advice to the president and others.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Madam Chair, I'd like to ask unanimous consent to enter this letter from the Electronic Privacy Information Center into the record.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Mrs. Blackburn. So ordered.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Doyle"> [The information appears at the conclusion of the hearing.] </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Doyle"> Thank you, and I would like to yield the remainder of my time to my colleague, Ms. Matsui. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Matsui</speaker> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Ms. Matsui">Thank you very much, Mr. Doyle, for yielding me time.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Ms. Matsui">Today's digital economy demands that we bolster the invisible infrastructure supporting wireless connectivity. Spectrum is the building block for innovation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Ms. Matsui">Working with NTIA we made significant progress in the last 8 years to free up federal spectrum for commercial use. Congressional oversight and cooperation from the administration was critical. As a result, we made 300 megahertz of spectrum available for the wireless broadband.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Ms. Matsui">We must have continued leadership from both branches of government including leaders at the agencies like the Department of Defense to expand this progress.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Ms. Matsui">We all know there is much more work to be done. The United States must lead the world in 5G and I look forward to working with my colleagues to free up more of our nation's airwaves for the wireless economy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Ms. Matsui">We have always been a nation of innovators and our spectrum policies should be no exception. With that, I yield back to the ranking member.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Ms. Matsui">Mrs. Blackburn. The gentleman yields back his time.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Ms. Matsui"> Chairman Walden is not here for his opening. Is there any member that would choose to take a portion of his time? Then let me reserve that in case he makes it up and at this time-- Mr. Pallone had requested time. Is that not correct? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Could I claim his time to yield for one more minute?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. Doyle"> Mrs. Blackburn. Absolutely you can claim the time and yield. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Thank you, Madam Chair. I appreciate it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Doyle"> Is there any member of the subcommittee that would like to have time? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Ruiz</speaker> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Ruiz"> Chair. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Doyle"> Yes, I'll yield to Mr. Ruiz. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Ruiz</speaker> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Mr. Ruiz">Thank you, Chairwoman and Ranking Member.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Mr. Ruiz">In today's digital age, access to broadband internet is not a luxury.
